claims.context: Phase transition at alpha = 4.27 is the hardest regime for random 3-SAT. Most solvers see sharp performance degradation here.
claims.verification: Generate random 3-SAT instances at n=1000, alpha=4.27. Measure fraction of satisfied clauses.

claims.description: Random dense Ising spin glass at n=1,000

claimed_result.display: Competitive with or exceeding SA, GA baselines

claims.context: Fully connected random Ising instances are the standard benchmark for combinatorial optimization solvers.
claims.verification: Generate random symmetric J matrix (Gaussian, mean 0), solve, compare energy to simulated annealing baseline.

claims.description: Random dense Ising spin glass at n=5,000
claims.context: Full connectivity at n=5000 means a 5000x5000 coupling matrix -- 25 million interactions. Most quantum annealers cannot handle this density.
claims.verification: Generate random symmetric 5000x5000 J matrix, solve, compare to available baselines.

claims.description: Max-Cut on random graphs at n=1,000
claims.context: Max-Cut is a canonical NP-hard graph problem with applications in circuit design and network partitioning.
claims.verification: Generate random sparse graph, solve Max-Cut, compare cut value to SDP relaxation bound.

claimed_result.display: Solved in under 40 minutes on single GPU

claims.context: D-Wave's quantum annealer supports 5,627 qubits with sparse Pegasus connectivity. The Daugherty Engine achieves full connectivity at 178x the variable count on a $1.57/hr GPU.

notes: D-Wave requires minor embedding for dense problems, reducing effective qubit count
Daugherty Engine runs on commodity NVIDIA GPUs with no cryogenic infrastructure
Full connectivity means no embedding overhead -- every spin talks to every other spin

blockchain_verification.purpose: Immutable timestamped proof of validation results
blockchain_verification.note: Certification receipts contain only public information -- no trade secrets are recorded on-chain
